thread.title: Green groups outraged by mine revelations
thread.title_full: Green groups outraged by mine revelations

title: Green groups outraged by mine revelations
text:
Wed, Jul 1, 2015, 1:11 PM AEST - Australia Markets close in 2 hrs 49 mins Green groups outraged by mine revelations AAP – 38 minutes ago Print 
Revelations that Queensland Treasury labelled a major Galilee Basin coal mine "unviable" have outraged green groups and renewed calls for an inquiry into fossil fuels. 
Documents released under under freedom of information laws have shown senior treasury officials expressed serious concerns about the approval of the $16.5 billion Carmichael mine because of Indian mining company Adani's high level of debt and unclear corporate structure, Fairfax Media reports. 
It showed former Premier Campbell Newman had gone against treasury advice by attempting to invest in the "white elephant" with state funds, Greens Senator for Queensland Larissa Waters said. 
"Queenslanders were furious with Campbell Newman for trying to squander funding that could have gone to education and health on the dying coal industry and they booted him out at the election," she said. 
"The same will happen to Tony Abbott if he follows in Campbell Newman's footsteps by giving handouts to big mining companies to dig up the Galilee through the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility." 
The Queensland opposition issued a written response saying it had never made a deal with Adani. 
"There were negotiations and due diligence was underway as part of the negotiations for investment infrastructure," a spokeswoman said. 
According to Greenpeace, the "deeply unhealthy" relationship between fossil fuel companies and elected officials undermined democracy and warranted an immediate review. 
"It's hard to fathom how taxpayers money could be given to a company to dredge the (Great Barrier) Reef without checking whether they have the capacity to pay it back," CEO David Ritter said. 
The views raised in the documents did not reflect those of the current government or Treasury, a spokeswoman for Minister for State Development Dr Anthony Lynham said. 
"We will meet all our election commitments on this project, both in terms of the dredging project at Abbot Point and not making direct government contributions towards funding the railway." @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Markets shrug off Greek "default" AAP 
After days of fretting about whether or not Greece would default on its debt, stock markets have shrugged off news …
